page.title: 11EVOLUTION OF RUGELEY
page.content: Rugeley owes its life to the market, transport and industry. Rugeley had a livestock market which no longer exists. The market hall has been demolished and replaced by a new building housing 43 stalls selling food and general goods. The Trent Valley is a transport corridor. Rugeley was on the coaching route between Stafford and Lichfield running parallel to Watling Street. The River Trent is shallowing near Rugeley but provided a passage for boats. The Trent and Mersey Canal provided much improved transport. The railway had a lesser effect, the small station is 1 mile out of town. Industry served local needs - iron, leather, brewing etc. Industry is now mainly coal mining, power stations and electrical goods but with many small service companies.
